Other indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions
column13: During FY22, we commenced reporting tenant-related emissions as part of Scope 3. We will continue working with our tenants into FY24 and beyond to understand Scope 3 emissions better and get a more complete picture of emissions ahead of Scope 3 reporting under ISSB, which is required from FY26. We have captured tenant data regularly since FY18, but this only includes tenants who purchase electricity through us.
column20: Tenant Emissions, Scope 3 Reporting, Carbon Footprint

column6: GHG emissions intensity
column13: During FY22, we began working with low-carbon energy company ENGIE to deliver electric vehicle fast-charging (DC) stations in car parks across our portfolio, expanding our offering and setting the benchmark for customer convenience. In FY23, we delivered 14 DC electric vehicle (EV) charging stations across 11 assets in partnership with Engie, in addition to a DC charging station installed at Karratha City, WA, with Horizon Power, for a total of 43 EV charging stations (AC/DC) at 15 centres across our portfolio. The introduction of EV chargers underscores our dedication to supporting cleaner transportation options and reaffirms our commitment to staying at the forefront of technological advancements.
column20: Electric Vehicle Charging, Low-carbon Energy, Cleaner Transportation

column6: Reduction of GHG emissions
column7: During the year, we saw a decrease of 8% in Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions, driven by a significant reduction in the carbon intensity of the national grid, specifically in Victoria, where half our portfolio is located.

column6: Emissions of ozone-depleting substances (ODS)
Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column7: As a retail property owner and manager, our centres are a major aggregator and users of materials, whether through our developments, refurbishment, tenant fit-outs and de-fits, or the day-to-day operations of our retailers. As a result, the disposal of materials is one of our most significant indirect environmental impacts.

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: Our materials recovery strategy aims to increase materials diversion from landfills, improving the diversion of organics (food waste), fibre (paper and cardboard), and mixed recycling. We deliver on this through ongoing engagement with our retailers, infrastructure reviews and upgrades so we have fit-for-purpose equipment at each centre, innovation, and collaboration with our service providers to identify best practices, processes and technologies.
column20: Materials Recovery, Waste Diversion, Organics Management

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: In FY23, we commenced work to understand what the circular economy means for Vicinity and how we can integrate its principles: 1. Eliminate waste and pollution, 2. Keep products and materials circulated for as long as possible, and 3. Regenerate nature into everything we do, from procurement to development to operations, and support our tenants to do the same.
column20: Circular Economy, Waste Elimination, Regenerative Practices

column7: In FY23, we spent $579,000 with social enterprises across our managed portfolio and became a member of Social Traders Ã¢ÂÂ a social enterprise procurement platform. Utilising such organisations to meet our procurement needs helps create positive social and economic change for those often marginalised or disadvantaged in our communities.

New employee hires and employee turnover
column8: Vicinity's third whole employee experience (EX) survey
column13: In February 2023, Vicinity's third whole employee experience (EX) survey was conducted, with 81% of team members completing the survey (+3% on the 2022 EX participation rate). The overall engagement score was measured at 66%, a decrease of 2% from the 2022 results. Comments increased by 25% this year, with 1,400+ comments provided. This trend reflects the continued work driving authentic communication and enabling a strong feedback culture.
column20: Employee Experience, Engagement Survey, Feedback Culture

column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
column13: Following the appointment of our new CEO, Peter Huddle, our Culture Roadmap for FY24-FY26 was developed. The Culture Roadmap will further strengthen the alignment of leadership behaviours through an accelerated focus on performance, the customer at the core, and creating an inclusive and safe environment.
column20: Culture Development, Inclusive Environment, Leadership Alignment

column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
column13: Our CEO presented a case study on our Respect@Vicinity program to the Property Council Champions of Change Coalition to share our learnings and support our broader industry maturity in May 2023. This Coalition is recognised for advancing gender equality and building respectful, inclusive workplaces.
column20: Respect Program, Gender Equality, Workplace Inclusion

column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
Parental leave
column13: Our teams told us through our EX survey that flexibility was essential and meant creating moments for team connection, informal learning opportunities, in-person collaboration and building deeper relationships. This year, we further embedded our hybrid working approach of 60:40, where we introduced three collaboration days within our offices to support the needs of our teams.

Occupation health and safety management system
column9: Health, Safety, Environment and Wellbeing Management System (HSEWMS)
column13: Our Health, Safety, Environment and Wellbeing Management System (HSEWMS) and our focus on continual improvement empower our people to work 'Safer, Healthier Together'. The HSEWMS is aligned to ISO 45001: Occupational Health and Safety Management Systems and ISO 14001: Environmental Management Systems, and its scope includes all Vicinity operations, assets, and our team members for all work activities.
column20: Health and Safety, Wellbeing Management, ISO Certification

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Our Mental Health and Wellbeing approach is to bring a systematic approach to managing mental health risk and promoting wellbeing. It has included conducting a Psychological Safety Risk Profiling exercise in 2023.\t
column20: Mental Health, Risk Profiling, Wellbeing Support

column6: Occupational health services
column7: Management System: develop and implement an integrated HSEW management system, including refreshing and incorporating Environmental, Development and Wellbeing procedures into the HSEWMS.

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column7: We employ various consultation methods through our HSEWMS procedures, including site health and safety committee meetings and HSEW team talks to have open, honest, and forthright consultations with all stakeholders.

Promotion of worker health
column13: We continue to recognise flexibility as an essential business enabler and a key focus of our DIB and workplace strategies. Flexibility is more than just working from home; it's also about flexible working hours, compressed work weeks, working from other Vicinity locations, and the more traditional part-time and job share arrangements.
column20: Workplace Flexibility, Work-life Balance, Job Sharing

column6: Promotion of worker health
column13: We aim to empower our team to improve their wellbeing by supporting individual wellbeing needs and helping them make positive health choices. To deliver a personalised user experience for our team members, we have a program of initiatives and resources to inspire meaningful and measurable change.
column20: Employee Wellbeing, Health Promotion, Support Programs

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: To align with the shift towards proactively managing mental health risks, Vicinity engaged AP Psychology & Consulting Services (APPCS) to design and deliver a three-phased project to understand the current business maturity and the mental health and wellbeing of our employees Ã¢ÂÂ to identify actions to improve our mental health and wellbeing maturity.
column20: Mental Health Assessment, Employee Support, Psychological Services

column6: Workers covered by an occupational health and safety management system
column13: As part of Vicinity's assurance program, Deloitte was engaged to complete a health, safety, and environment audit, looking at the top priority safety risks at 15 of Vicinity's locations and the controls used to manage these risks. A further 45 centres completed HSEW self-assessments.
column20: Safety Audit, Risk Management, Environmental Compliance
